snippet: Years before a scathing Senate report, an internal review found that the C.I.A. had repeatedly overstated the value of intelligence gained from brutal interrogation techniques.
abstract: Central Intelligence Agency internal report, known as Panetta Review, showed that agency had repeatedly overstated worth of intelligence gained from brutal interrogations of some of its detainees; contents of review, ordered in 2009 by CIA's director at the time, Leon E Panetta, is central to arguments over Senate Intelligence Committee's conclusions about use of torture.
lead_paragraph: Years before a scathing Senate report, an internal review found that the C.I.A. had repeatedly overstated the value of intelligence gained from brutal interrogation techniques.

headline.main: C.I.A. Report Found Value of Brutal Interrogation Was Inflated
headline.print_headline: C.I.A. Report Found Value of Brutal Interrogation Was Inflated
